top_comment.text:
even though i have never heard this term before today that is pretty much 
how i have always have been. I've always had a sort of a, "What will be, 
will be" attitude. I've actually had a bit of the opposite problem as you 
because i am American, and therefore my ideals have not always been 
understood very well by my peers. Like people who get mad over things that 
cannot be helped and loose there temper i have always found them to be 
incredibly childish... a child looses his temper in public, being an adult, 
to me, has always meant being able to control that aspect of yourself. and 
even though that has always bothered me, i still end up with the mind set 
that that is just how things are and it cannot be helped. Its sort of like 
que sera sera.﻿
top_comment.author: RavenNight

comments.text:
oh haha no problem. I never realized before that my ideals where actually a 
norm someplace else. Thank you for that :3. it makes me feel much less 
alone on the subject
comments.author: RavenNight

comments.text:
"a child looses his temper in public, being an adult, to me, has always 
meant being able to control that aspect of yourself"
Of course this should be common sense most places, but this sounds very 
Japanese to me because Jun's told me this quite a few times! I think this 
thought process is probably more pronounced in Japan, too. Japanese people 
are typically VERY well in control of themselves, and that was another 
thing that was surprising to me when I first visited. :) That they don't 
often get upset and yell or become moody when something unfair or stupid 
happens, and when foreigners *do* we can end up isolating ourselves and 
being pushed away. This was one of the main points I wanted to make in my 
What not to do in Japan video when I tried to talk about not getting 
emotional. I wish I had been able to explain it this clearly!! Thank you! 
m(_ _)m

comments.text:
Your argument is extremely flawed. No one in the world can ever completely 
understand a culture that is different from their own or they did not grow 
up in. Culture shock does not mean something like "wow this culture is so 
weird and i don't like it" kind of shock. It's a shock because if you went 
to a country thats on the other side of the globe where there's a culture 
that has developed almost completely separately from the one you grew up 
in. Things are different, things are not like they are at home. The food is 
different, people behave differently, buildings look different, the 
landscape is different. You can't expect someone to completely understand 
something that is new or different from what they are used to and that is 
not even remotely related to racism. Sure misunderstanding can lead to some 
racist ideas but it's natural for anyone to be confused about something 
they have never experienced before. Heck I get culture shock in my own 
country. Please do your research before you make such an incorrect 
statement.

top_comment.text:
はじめまして^^
「しょうがない」という言葉はpositiveな言葉だと思います。
起きてしまったこと＝過去のことなので、起きたことはくつがえせません。
このとき重要なのは、次にどうするか？どう問題に対応するか？なので
起きてしまったことにたいしては「しょうがない」と一度流して次どうするかを考える。
positiveでいるためにはとても重要な言葉なのかもしれませんね^^﻿
top_comment.author: FttttttttF

comments.text:
同感です。
もう１つ付け加えるなら日本人は基本的に温厚な性格だからかもしれません。
事を荒立てることを極端に避けるので、たとえ相手が悪くても「しょうがない」とか「別に気にしなくていいよ」てな感じで、ある程度のことは寛大に流してしまうところがありますね。
あとはスポーツなどでも明らかにミスしたチームメイトを励ますときに「しょうがないよ」と良く言ったりしますが、ミスした仲間が傷つかないように責めないようにする為に使ってると思います。
改めて考えてみると「しょうがない」って言葉は状況によって色々と意味が違ってておもしろいですね:D
comments.author: Jackson Weaver

comments.text:
Maybe your interpretation is correct.(i' m not good at English,sorry...)
Thank you for your comment.^^
comments.author: FttttttttF

comments.text:
This so much! If I understand correctly, the gist of this comment is, 
"Shouganai is sort of positive, because your focus goes into making sure 
the next time goes more smoothly, instead of trying to change the past." I 
feel like everyone in the world needs to hear this, but particularly 
Americans. There's this attitude of not just, "I need to punish someone for 
justice," but also, "If I show compassion and understanding at all, and try 
to solve the conflict instead of digging my heels in and escalating it, 
then I'm weak and I'm giving in," and that attitude really isn't good for 
anyone. Very nice video, and an important message.
comments.author: Lavender Mint Rose

top_comment.text:
It depends. When bad things happen to me that can't be helped such as being 
diagnosed with a very rare incurable disease like I have I'd be 
disappointed but I'd accept it and try to make it work out in the best way 
possible for me... If it's about other people though, I just can't watch 
them suffer. When something happens to my fiancee he would always say 仕方ない 
or しょうがない and just leave it as it is. He never really fights for things and 
thinks it'd all happen for a reason and maybe he wouldn't deserve any 
better. When people act like that I always want to help and push them to 
stand up for themselves. Even if it's not about me personally I would feel 
so helpless and not being able to actively help because I'm still trapped 
on the other side of the planet just makes it all worse... ﻿

comments.author: Rachel & Jun

top_comment.text:
The phrase doesn't seem too bad. To me it feels like the American 
equivalent to "whatever." Or "meh." And I do agree that Americans are built 
with a huge sense of justice in them, if they allow it. A lot of people 
don't care one way or another. But they're weird. :P

On that though, I think the American sense of justice is pushed too high in 
some people. That's why we have the overwhelming amount of suing in this 
country. It's okay to fix what is wrong, but some cases are pointless. "I'm 
emotionally distraught because she fired me, even though I come to work 
late, never care about my appearance, still can't do the job after a year 
of working there, and a slew of other things." (Yeah, I'm exaggerating.) 
But the point is people who don't get their way sometimes take it to the 
extreme. And that's just a folly on their part. I guess this would be the 
people who think of themselves on a platform and are better than other 
people. Everybody is the same, we just have different thoughts and ways to 
go about things, but we are all the same and should be treated equally. 
It's okay to be selfish, but keep it within bounds. As long as nobody is 
hurt. 

Wow, that got preachy. :/

Sorry, my mind went off on a tangent. I haven't done any fiction writing 
today, so I blame that. :P    ﻿
top_comment.author: TheBookHito

comments.text: Not exactly the same mentality
comments.author: MrSpeedyD3

comments.text:
+Jason Wilkins I am somewhat of a Japanese and Korean drama/movie fanatic. 
One theme that pops up VERY often in Japanese movies and TV dramas is the 
idea of someone going against the system - quite often a cop or other 
figure in the legal system, but nearly always someone in the government. 
(Oddly, though Japanese and Korean cultures are similar in many ways, you 
seldom see this in Korean shows).

Nearly always the character is ostracized and posted to some backwater 
precinct or similar office, where they shake things up win in the end. What 
I find interesting is that this theme is so common in movies and shows, but 
so rare in real life. 

And the "moral panic" shows up a lot in those shows also - I have seen it 
go from school bullying, to spousal abuse, to the most recent theme, which 
is police incompetence.
comments.author: Warren Lauzon

comments.text:
+Warren Lauzon I think we may be getting away from しょがない and into something 
broader. 

Hmm, but when I think more about it, it does seem like much of the hidden 
injustice in Japan can be attributed to しょがない, because injustice really 
does require people to stand up and fight for it and that is something the 
Japanese are taught not to do.

It is interesting that occasionally Japan will have a great moral panic 
about something and make an example out of somebody. This probably 
functions as a safety valve.
comments.author: Jason Wilkins

comments.text:
+Jason Wilkins The fact is, you cannot trust all the metrics from Japan, as 
they are sometimes skewed. One of the hidden secrets is the Japanese murder 
rate vs suicide rate - there have been instances where instead of something 
being labeled as an unsolved murder, it is listed as a suicide in order to 
put into the "solved" column.
comments.author: Warren Lauzon

comments.text:
+LordVader1094 far from it. Shouganai can have a sinister side. Like, 
letting children stay locked up in their room instead of getting 
psychiatric help. Or letting bullying go unchecked. 

Generally Japan appears better because the metrics we use to measure it are 
the kinds of things they sweep under the rug and hide.

An unhappy family in America can be heard through the walls. Just because 
the Japanese aren't yelling at each other doesn't mean all the families are 
happy! They are just more polite.
comments.author: Jason Wilkins

comments.text: +LordVader1094 If you lived there for a while, you might not think so.

ours.

comments.text:
I don't really think it's the shouganai, but more that they often feel 
over-obligated to school/rules/company. A sense of loyalty/honor is of 
important, but some Japanese tend to throw their life mostly away because 
they think they have to give priority to the job (which in a lot of cases 
has to be done, but Japanese do it too much I would say)

It's like they were born to doing that and nothing else, instead of they 
were born and that happened to be around.

They have a very bad work-life balance. But if you ask Japanese what they 
would actually want, most would say that they would be a better work-life 
balance, but nobody tries to go for it.

That is my culture shock with the shouganai.

comments.text:
I hear shouganai in anime quite a bit and it seems healthy there because 
it's usually about something like not getting mad that somebody is 
inconveniencing you by just being themselves (non malicious behavior). It 
almost seems like an effort to get along.

But if it extends to things like not caring if somebody breaks your stuff 
or costs you a lot of money and time then that's not good. People shouldn't 
get along *that* well.

top_comment.text:
You're understanding of Shouganai kinda reminds me of when I started to 
understand what it means to be lazy in Italy. Italians are notorious for 
being lazy people but they understand being lazy differently than us 
Americans. To us Americans, being lazy means lacking work ethic. To 
Italians being lazy means taking your time and not getting stressed out. In 
fact, it is a compliment in Italy to be called lazy or "pigro" in Italian.

Italians don't lack work ethic, they are hard working people. They just 
don't let themselves get stressed out and get things done when they are 
able to instead of getting things done under a certain deadline. At least 
that's how I've come to understand it.﻿

top_comment.text:
Honestly this is the exact opposite of how I think. Like, if I lose my 
wallet, which has, among other things
-my debit card
-my government I.D.
-my student I.D.
-my library card
I'm not just gonna shrug my shoulders and say "Oh well, what can you do?" 
I'm gonna get pissed off. That means I'd have to:
-go through the tedious process of getting up at like 3-4 in the morning 
and stand in line for who knows how long, THEN sit inside and wait for who 
knows how long just to replace my I.D.
-call my bank and tell them to cancel my debit card, then have it replaced
-get a new student I.D.
-get a new library card
All this when I have enough stuff to do during the week. It's too much to 
deal with. When crap is just falling down all around you, "shouganai" is 
just not applicable. That's how I see it. Things can only get so bad before 
it just stops working as a coping mechanic.

But then again I've never had a good temper so take that how you will.﻿
top_comment.author: thapoint09

comments.text:
+thapoint09 That's understandable of course xD I wasn't trying to say 
everyone needs to be like that, I was just explaining what the mindset 
behind shouganai might be. If it's just in your nature then it can't be 
helped, and there's no need to feel bad about it.
comments.author: Araf Hossain

comments.text:
And while I can respect that, it's just not something I'm capable of doing 
9 times out of 10 at this point in my life. If something crappy happens to 
me, I'm gonna throw a fuss. It's just in my character. In fact, the only 
time I can recall *not* throwing a fuss - which kinda surprised me - is 
when I missed my bus to take me to my college campus from the train station 
and I was all but prepared to screw it and walk there. Thank goodness that 
second bus came shortly after I started.
comments.author: thapoint09

comments.text:
Wanting to complain is only natural, but it isn't productive. Like in the 
scenario you mentioned above, getting angry wouldn't fix things, it would 
only waste your energy and time. I think the concept of shouganai is that, 
since bad things inevitably will happen to us, we should direct our energy 
and time towards recovering and repairing the situation, rather than 
directing it towards being upset.
comments.author: Araf Hossain

comments.text:
Okay, that makes sense. Still, me being the person I am, it's just not in 
my character to move forward without complaining just a *little*.
comments.author: thapoint09

comments.text:
+thapoint09 You got that completely wrong.

"shiyou ga nai" doesn't mean defeatism. It means "it is what it is, no 
reason to complain, let's move forward".
Just think about how fast Japanese repaired everything after the massive 
Tsunami in 3/11.

Now compare that with how slow the damages of Katrina were repaired.
Saying "Well, fuck me" isn't going to fix anything.

http://assets.inhabitat.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2011/03/japanese-highway-before-and-after.jpg
This is shouganai. This is Japan.

comments.text:
Oh that would be the correct, literal translation.

However, it's used as an argument against action after the fact by 
attributing it to conditions outside of the reach of involved persons 
(whether because forgetting is part of the human condition or because a 
meteorite hit your car which no one could have stopped) If you tell people, 
in English, "nothing could have been done about it," they're likely to take 
that as a sign of your apathy. "Shit happens" is basically a condensed 
version of the general reasoning you would give for why nothing could have 
been done about a certain situation.
comments.author: ShiroiKage009

top_comment.text:
I don't agree with the statement that Americans have a strong sense of 
justice. Instead, I would call it a strong sense of entitlement. It's the 
sense that nothing bad should ever happen to you, no matter how small. For 
example, if someone breaks your cup, you feel as if someone owes you for 
the inconvenience of you losing the use of your cup.
Being able to let things go if they're small enough just reduces the amount 
of stress in your life.﻿
top_comment.author: sleazybtd

feeling entitled.
comments.author: sleazybtd

comments.text:
Fair is a word that has many interpretations. At its most basic it means 
treating people as they deserve to be treated. Reward the just and punish 
the wicked. An admirable concept. The trouble comes when one must define 
"just" and "wicked".

Unfortunately, many consider the poor to be lazy and irresponsible and the 
homosexual to be libidinous and abomninable.

There are approximately 300 million people in the United States, the vast 
majority of which have been told their entire lives that they can make the 
world a better place. Sadly, some people have rather fucked up visions of a 
"better place".
comments.author: Joss Goyanko

+Joss Goyanko
I'm thinking more along the line of the rich who game the system to become

of gay marriage by saying that if gay marriage was banned, the gays would 
not be able to get their marriage tax break, therefore they end up paying

comments.author: sleazybtd

comments.text:
A couple of years ago psychologists came up with a simple game to determine 
how subjects would react when faced with issues of resource distribution 
and unfairness. The game was simple. 

There would be two subjects, both strangers, Person A and Person B. A would 
be given a hundred dollars and would have to decide how to split the money 
between A and B. If B agreed to the offer, they would split the money, but 
if B said no then neither party would get any money. 

When both subjects were American, Person A would always suggest a 50/50 
split. In instances where Person A was a confederate working for the 
researchers and would suggest an uneven split, say 70/30, Subject B would 
almost always say no.

Although other tested nationalities also said refused, no group had a 
higher rate of refusal than the Americans. They seemed to possess an innate 
sense of fairness and justice in their culture which seemed to compel them 
to punish what they perceived as unfairness.

There's a reason Americans have been the most ardent supporters of 
capitalism in the 20th and 21st century. There's a reason American 
literature invented the Superhero. There's a reason the crime shows like 
Law & Order and CSI are so phenomenally popular in the US.

Yes, sometimes Americans act entitled. But they do it because in their 
mindset, they can change the world; in fact it is their duty to change the 
world and make it better. And if they have to step on a few toes to make it 
happen, then so be it.
comments.author: Joss Goyanko

comments.text:
There are certainly a lot of entitled people in America, can't argue with 
that, but I think that's over simplifying it. I agree with Rachel that 
Americans have a strong sense of justice because it's not just things that

examples in this video were about her feeling that other people should have 
justice for the things that happened to them.

top_comment.text:
"Hakuna matata. Sometimes bad things happen and there's nothing you can do 
about it.So why worry?" - Simba. 

This is something I learned early on in life, thanks to The Lion King. 
Aha.(Although his use of it in that situation wasn't entirely good, but I 
understood that it wasn't always a bad thing to go by). But yeah, a lot of 
times I find it's better to just let things go when you can't do anything 
to change them. Although sometimes I think that something should be done, 
for example if someone was careless and broke something expensive or 
injured you (ex: DRUNK DRIVER injuring you) then you should sue. However, 
if it was truly an accident then I feel it should be let go... I think I 
also got this attitude from my mom. My little brother ran into traffic when 
he was young and this poor little old lady hit him. He got hurt, of 
course... but he suffered nothing in lasting damage. The old lady seemed 
sincerely upset and worried about him and it really wasn't her fault. I 
think a lot of Americans would have sued her because they could but my mom 
said, "It wasn't your fault, don't worry about it." and let it go. 

Anyway, I think "Shouganai" is healthy in some situations but people need 
to have an understanding of when it is okay to be upset about something and 
when it's okay to stand up for yourself if there's a possibility of a 
favorable outcome. (If there's no chance of getting 'justice' then there's 
no point in worrying over it. Just let it go!) 

That's my two cents. Great video, Rachel. ^^﻿
top_comment.author: ArtieKirkland

comments.text:
+Payper Planes  "If you run into the street and get hit = YOUR fault." ... 
What? That's like saying "it's the girls fault for being raped because she 
was wearing short shorts." Sure you can do some things to LOWER the risk, 
but you can't say that it's ONE HUNDRED PERCENT YOUR FAULT for being hit by 
a car.

Pretty sure if you were walking on the sidewalk and got hit by some drunk 
driver you wouldn't be like "Oh can't be helped. My fault for being on the 
sidewalk"
comments.author: Reina

comments.text:
The point I was bringing forth was that my mom recognized it wasn't the old 
lady's fault and so she didn't attempt to sue as so many others would have. 
(And no, my mom wasn't even home - it was his father who was watching him, 
who left us long ago. I dont really care if you want to point fingers at 
him since he was a terrible father anyway but that's not the point I'm 
getting at here...). 

The point you bring up is irrelevant, even if I believed that someone was 
particularly at fault. Because the point I'm bringing up is that many 
Americans still would have tried to blame someone else and sue them, no 
matter who is at fault.
comments.author: ArtieKirkland

comments.text:
"My brother was 3 and saw his aunt across the street and bolted off before 
anyone could stop him. It's not like it was really HIS fault, he didn't 
know any better."

In that case it was your mother's fault (or whoever's care he was in), 
because she didn't take better care of him.

"I SAID my mom said it wasn't her fault. "

When you said "her," I take it you mean the "old lady," because it 
*definitely* was your mother's fault. You stated that she "let it go," as 
if she somehow had *any right* to claim money for damages. You also seemed 
to try to make it sound like it was a "faultless" situation - I was making 
it clear that someone *definitely* was at fault - apparently your mother - 
 and that she had *no right* at all to claim any damages - she could *sue*, 
sure, but did she have any *right*? Not a chance in hell!

You can think I'm rude as much as you like, I'm just stating the facts 
truthfully. I don't need to sugarcoat them to suit your needs.
comments.author: Payper Planes

comments.text: ^ hhmm.... what's the word again?... hakuna... hakuna matata?

comments.author: ArtieKirkland

comments.text:
+ArtieKirkland  "I think a lot of Americans would have sued her because 
they could but my mom said, 'It wasn't your fault, don't worry about it.' 
and let it go."

That's because it *wasn't* her fault.  It *wasn't* something that "couldn't 
be helped," your little brother could have not been as stupid and run out 
into the street, *THAT*'s how it could have been helped. It was completely 
*HIS* FAULT, even if he had died, and only worthless trash would even 
*think* about suing her or get upset at her.

*You are responsible for your own actions.* If you run into the street and 
get hit = YOUR fault. If you wear dark clothing at night and get run over 
because you crossed a street where there are no light = YOUR fault. If you 
ride a bicycle at night without light and get run over = YOUR fault - and 
those are ALL situations that *could* have been helped with a little 
thinking on that person's part.

comments.author: mamobster1500

top_comment.text:
Great video! Being someone who has studied Japanese in university and by 
myself, I have experienced the concept of "shouganai," although I've never 
actually heard anyone say it. My Japanese professors are all native 
Japanese who grew up with the Japanese system and came here for grad school 
or whatever and then just decided to stay, so I'm surprised they never say 
it. Maybe the American mindset has infiltrated their thinking and, like you 
with sort of realizing it and accepting it, they see that here in America, 
we don't just say "shouganai" and let things go. (I dunno. Maybe I'll ask 
my professor when I go to school on Monday what he thinks about this.) And 
since I have yet to actually go to Japan (although it looks very likely 
that I'll be going there for a few weeks this summer as part of a school 
project), I have yet to hear a Japanese person say to me, "Shouganai."
I don't know if you watch her videos or whatever, but Mary (kawaiijutsu) 
talked about this in a video of hers called "Japanese Bureaucracy" about 
the Japanese saying "shouganai" even when it could be helped. What she does 
is if she hears a Japanese person say "shouganai," not when something 
happens and you can't do anything about it, but when something happens that 
can be helped, she replies with, "Iie, shou ga aru." which I think is a 
very clever thing to do.
I think that when I go to Japan, if I hear someone say "shouganai" and yet 
there can be something done to help the situation, I might just start 
giggling uncontrollably in response. I realize that there are some things 
that, as foreigners, we have to accept if we want to live in Japan (such as 
people staring at us because we're gaijin and asking us random things, like 
"you can use chopsticks even though you're a gaijin?" in which case we do 
have to say "shouganai" because the Japanese people might not realize that 
gaijin can use chopsticks, etc.) But "shouganai" is definitely something 
that I refuse to accept in the case of "It can be helped, but we're just 
not going to do anything about it because that would cause trouble for 
others."
Reading all the comments on this video, people seem to be making 
comparisons to things like "Que sera sera" and "hakuna matata," and I do 
agree that it can be unhealthy to stress out about everything. I do have a 
"shouganai" type attitude if something unexpected happens and there can't 
be anything done to change it, but if there's something I can do to change 
the current situation for the better, then I'll do it rather than just sit 
around and say "it can't be helped."﻿
top_comment.author: Otaku Madness

comments.text:
I agree with all of this. I think it's important to understand the nuance 
of situations. It's not that you should just accept things as they are and 
try not to rock the boat, and it's not that you should try to stand up for 
yourself if you feel wronged regardless of how people feel about you doing 
so. Such actions, like everything else, are contextual, and come in 
degrees, and it's faulty thinking to apply one general mindset to all kinds 
of different situations.

Basically, be adaptable.

captions.text:
Hey guys! So, today I want to talk about what
was probably the first major culture shock

I had when I went to Japan. And it's about
the phrase "shouganai" or "shikataganai."

And this translates in English to the phrase,
"It can't be helped." And it's used in the

context of something like... Let's say it's
raining outside and you forgot your umbrella.

You say, "Shouganai. Ah well. It can't be
helped. Whatever. I forgot my umbrella so

I'll just have to deal with it."
And the first time I went to Japan, I heard

this all of the time. I stayed in an international
dorm with other international students and

we had Japanese Resident Assistants, or RAs.
And their jobs were VERY strict. They had

very strict rules. Like they couldn't go hang
out with their friends, they couldn't spend

the night anywhere else except for the dorm,
they had to be at the dorm almost all of the

hours of the day that they weren't in class
or doing like absolutely necessary shopping.

They had to help the students with their homework,
and help them buy things, and any other problems

that came up, so they were extremely busy.
And I knew one RA who spent so much time helping

the students that they got almost no sleep
at all and their grades plummeted because

they didn't have time to do their own homework
or to study for their own classes.

And I would get so frustrated for them. I
would be like, "Tell the students sometimes,

'No, you can't help them. You need to focus
on your own work sometimes.' You have to take

care of yourself, too." And they would just
be like, "Shouganai." I picked this job. That's

just the way it is and those are the rules."
And there were other cases where some international

students would accidentally break the RA's
stuff, and the RA's would be like, "Shouganai."

And I'd be like, "NO!! Go find the person
who did that and get them to pay for it!!

They have to pay for it if they broke it!
You can't just like let them get away with

it!"
It drove me crazy that they would say "Shouganai"

for all of these things that I felt like they
needed to fight for. And I think that's because

in our culture in America, we're raised with
an extremely strong sense of justice. Like

good versus evil, and people are right or
wrong. And the wrong people—they have to

pay! No matter what, they have to pay! And
I may have a stronger sense of justice than

most people so maybe I'm even a little farther
than a lot of American people. But this is

what we grew up with. If something happens
to you and you tell your friends, your friends

are going to tell you like, "Don't stand for
that! Go talk to the manager! Go write a letter!"

or something. And that's probably why we have
such a strong suing culture in America, because

people feel like they need to be vindicated
when something happens to them.

And it drove me crazy in Japan because it
seemed like people just let things go and

they didn't stand up for themselves. If you
had asked me when I studied abroad in Japan

what I disliked about Japan the most, I definitely
would have said, "Shouganai." I absolutely

hated that phrase.
And it wasn't until I moved back home to America...

Because Jun and I had started dating and gotten
engaged and we knew that I had signed a contract

with my job before I ever even met Jun and
it could be four years until we could be together.

And actually as of a couple days ago it HAS
been four years and we're still not together.

There were a couple opportunities with my
job where I could potentially move to Japan.

And I put all of my effort into making sure
I was absolutely the best candidate for the

Japan jobs. And I worked for this for years.
I planned for years and did absolutely everything

I could to get to Japan so Jun and I could
be together sooner.

And every single time that benchmark came
where I could have gone to Japan, I failed.

And it wasn't just failing to get to Japan
to be with Jun, but all sorts of other things

would happen at the same time. Like you guys
know, my stuff got shipped to Korea and I

haven't seen like half of the stuff I own
in a year and a half or something. It's been

a really long time. And I had the heart problem.
Woo! Suddenly rare heart condition! pops up.

And there would be problems with like my taxes,
and problems with appointments, and problems

with my car. It would just all come at the
same time. And it was too much to handle.

It's devastating. No one can handle that much
stuff at once without kind of breaking down

a little bit and going crazy.
And it was around that time when I started

to rethink what "shouganai" actually means.
And I started to think, maybe "shouganai"

doesn't mean you're weak or you won't stand
up for yourself. But maybe it's actually a

healthy mindset to have when bad things happen
to you. If you can just accept the things

that happen to you without getting stressed
out or freaking out about them, and you can

say, "All right! Whatever. So I had an appointment
and you rescheduled it for this morning without

telling me and I missed it and now I'm in
trouble. Okay, well-shouganai. Whatever. That's

not my fault. So I'll just have to reschedule
my appointment, I guess.

And I actually came to rely on that sort of
attitude a lot when all of this stuff would

happen to me. I wouldn't say it's one of the
main things that has helped me get through,

but I would say it has played its fair role.
So I really have come to have a different

understanding of "shouganai," I think. I think
it can actually be a good thing for people.

I'm curious about you guys and your experiences
in Japan. Have you ever heard Japanese people

use "shouganai" or "shikata ga nai" in absolutely
awful situations where you're like, "No! Don't

do that! Just stand up for yourself! Do something
about it!" Or are you more of the type of

person who leans toward "shouganai" and you
understand that, and that's kind of your attitude

about things? I'm curious where all of you
stand because I've changed completely about

it in the past four years. So, thanks for
watching, guys, and I'll see you next time!

title: Culture shock: Shouganai カルチャーショック：しょうがない
